Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Energetic Regulation of Seasonal Sickness Behaviors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Upon infection, animals display a collection of behaviors called "sickness behaviors." Studies of sickness behaviors in seasonally breeding species have shown that the magnitude of an animal's response to infection varies across seasons. Seasonal modulation of sickness behaviors may be a mechanism to avoid over-expending energy or missing a reproductive opportunity, but suppressing the expression of these behaviors may put an organism at greater risk of not being able to clear an infection. Therefore, the degree to which an organism expresses sickness will have profound effects on its survival and reproductive success. When comparing across studies, a clear pattern emerges in that sickness behaviors are attenuated in the season in which an animal has the lowest energy reserves; however, the causative nature of this relationship has not been tested experimentally. The project's working hypothesis is that seasonal variation in sickness behaviors is due to seasonal variation in energy stores. The specific aims of the research are to: 1) determine the contributions of seasonal changes in food availability on sickness behaviors, 2) determine how metabolic hormones influence variation in sickness behaviors, and 3) evaluate the contributions of experimental manipulations of food availability and metabolic hormones on endocrine and immunological factors that directly mediate sickness behavior in seasonally breeding Siberian hamsters. An understanding of the physiological signals that act to modulate the display of sickness behaviors will enhance our knowledge of how environmental conditions affect how an animal responds to an infection. The results of this research will contribute to the current initiatives to understand disease susceptibility as a function of pathogen prevalence (i.e., disease ecology) and host immune function (i.e., ecoimmunology). Additionally, this work has provided opportunities to engage diverse undergraduates in research training and will continue to do so as these projects are completed.

Data will be made available on Research Data Complex (RDC), http://pervasive.iu.edu/hps/rdc

POR.DRECONTENT:
To ensure survival and reproductive success, animals must optimally allocate energy among various physiological and behavioral processes while inhabiting environments that change predictably across and unpredictably within seasons. In this project, we examined mechanisms by which a seasonally-breeding rodent modulates the intensity of its sickness responses to a simulated infection across seasons. Siberian hamsters (Phodopus sungorus) inhibit reproduction and display lower body masses, lower levels of the adipose hormone leptin, and less intense sickness responses when housed in short, winter-like days compared to long, summer-like days. We used several techniques to modulate the internal energetic state of the hamsters (i.e., food restriction, manipulation of the energetic hormones leptin and insulin, pharmacological induction of glucose deprivation) to determine its role in the seasonal regulation of sickness intensity. While working on this project, we completed three major experiments.

In our first experiment, we used food restriction to induce short-day-like patterns of body mass loss in long-day hamsters. We predicted that if seasonal changes in body mass modulate variation in sickness intensity, then long-day food-restricted animals would show short-day-like sickness. We discovered that long-day food restricted animals showed more short-day-like body mass loss, anorexia, and hypothermia in response to sickness, suggesting that seasonal changes in body mass may mediate some of the variation in sickness intensity across the seasons. However, the anorexic and hypothermic responses of the long-day food-restricted group fell intermediate between those of the unrestricted short-day and long-day groups, despite no differences in body mass between the long-day food-restricted and unrestricted short-day groups. These results suggest that seasonal changes in body mass influence sickness but cannot explain all variation in intensity.

In the second experiment,  we examined if seasonal variation in sickness is mediated by changes in leptin, a signal of available fat stores. We predicted that if seasonal variation in sickness is correlated with available fat stores, then providing short-day hamsters with leptin to simulate increased fat levels, similar to those of long-day animals, would increase sickness intensity (i.e., enhanced fever or reduced hypothermia, increased anorexia and body mass loss). We found that providing short-day hamsters with leptin modulated sickness-induced hypothermia, such that it was attenuated in this group as compared to control hamsters. This result suggests that seasonal variation in leptin may mediate the magnitude of sickness-induced body temperature changes. Contrary to predictions, sickness-induced anorexia was attenuated, rather than enhanced, in short-day leptin-treated animals, indicating that seasonal changes in leptin do not modulate seasonal sickness intensity as a whole. Rather, different sickness symptoms may be coordinated by other energetic (or non-energetic) signals. 

In the final experiment, we investigated how sickness intensity is modulated in response to short-term, unpredictable changes in glucose. We found that glucose deprivation resulted in increased sickness-induced hypothermia, yet had no effects on sickness-induced anorexia and body mass, suggesting that glucose availability limits the magnitude of at least one energetically-expensive sickness symptom but not all symptoms.
